WRITING.TITLE: World Boss A Treasure Box is OP

WRITING.TEXT: I will try to answer your questions in order... 1. Drop rates are the same for A+ through F Those rates are all 0.0001% to get anything other than mana, crappy runes, and low essences... 2. Skillups will add to your overall damage. The skillups are more or less depending on how that monster is balanced against others of its kind. All skillups are not equal, but most are based off of the same percentages we typically see (i.e. +10% damage) 3. Yes there has been extensive research on the world boss... The results are as you would expect... RNG is a B*TCH and you will get crap for the crap time you spend building your crappy mons... Good Luck and Happy Hunting!

I think we have different definitions of "fine"
So you dont have an issue with the deficit growth? Troops overseas? Interest rates at all time lows? A healthcare system that is a trainwreck? Regulations on everything on the rise?
Dont get me wrong. I cant vote for someone who completely dismisses climate change and calls it a fabrication from the Chinese.

I agree that growth will help with the deficit and the interest rates, but regulations on big businesses will slow that down. We have been going through increased regulations in the banks, the auto industry, energy (though I agree with most), healthcare, etc. I want smaller government involvement and I think that will help drive business growth. Businesses are fleeing the country for better options because of taxes and regulations. Healthcare might be my biggest issue right behind Climate Change. The ACA has been great for people to be insured, but the system is still broken. Healthcare is still run by the insurance payers and they are holding people hostage. Healthcare needs to focus on quality and access. Insurance payers are going out of their way to make it harder for people to access care. Hospital systems need to adapt too, but the margins are so small that they can not properly invest in the future needs. The payers make sure of that. The troops are still over there fighting in countries that dont even want our help anymore. We continue to spread our resources too thin across too many countries because we are the first to jump in to help. Bring them home and lets secure our allies first and then jump into humanitarian aid. Sorry these are out of order from my previous post and your response, but I lumped a few together as you can see.
Any clue as to why this question isnt on the front page of this sub or at least in the "New" section?

WRITING.TITLE: Could Splenda be the reason I am stalled? [Question]
WRITING.TEXT: Simple question. I have been stalled out for about 4 weeks. I dove back into the wiki and saw that Splenda is not highly recommended and I use that in my daily coffee. Could that be the reason my weight loss has stalled? I am no biologist, but I am willing to try to make any change I need to. Can you suggest a different sweetener for my morning (and sometimes afternoon), coffee?

I don't track my calories very strictly because I eat very simply. Chicken, very little bacon, lettuce, and coffee... I am not someone that needs a ton of variety, but rather simple and quick meals because of my schedule. Also, yes I use the packets of Splenda.
SW 204 CW 198 GW 185 I eat somewhere between 1200-1500 calories a day. I don't own a food scale.
How does a food scale help me?
I eat simply, I know how much chicken I eat, how much bacon I eat, etc. weighing my food will only make me stop doing keto. That is an extra step in my day that I don't have time to add.

You don't know me or my situation. I think it's pretty straight forward what I just told you. I know how much I'm eating without a scale because I have nutritional values of each of the objects I am eating. I'm not sure how a scale would benefit me.

When I say "Training Staff" I mean the whole team from strength and conditioning, to trainers, to medical staff, to rehab. They need a reevaluation of all of the parts of not a total overhaul. Teams employ all types of doctors and other specialized licensed medical staff to treat and diagnose all types of injuries. The team isn't giving the players the best chance at success.

No one and I mean no one had any clue he would all of a sudden turn into a MVP candidate. He was always good at hitting for average, he was a mess in the field, and he didn't drive in runs. He had an outstanding post season and he got paid for it, no one knew he would have been this good.

I dont think this is a surprise... This team will not hit for average. it is built for long balls and a few timely hits, which they are not getting... ever... Do I think that is ok? No. Does it make me sad? Yes, very much so.
Please do, give us a shoutout as well.

Jose actually looks hurt... It might just be his age, but he seems to be a lot slower at the plate. Watching him swing right now is almost painful to watch. He is standing up more than ever, he never had great pitch selection, but he is swinging at everything right now and he seems to be just... slow... and one thing we want a No Slow Jose...

Sabermetrics are great and all, but you need an entire team built on that mentality, not just one or two players. The stats are terrible for all the sabermetric fans out there, BA with RISP, OPS, WAR, even BA on balls in play is terrible... Yes we have some shining moments with big homeruns, but how many teams win deep into the postseason that depend on HRs as their run production?

Well this story is a bit one sided isn't it? We are also currently looking at a shortage of doctors, nurses, and other medical professions because of how the system works and how we incentivise people within the industry. Let's take the marketing out of it and put the patient in the center again. Then we can start having more meaningful discussions about health care reform.

WRITING.TITLE: This has now affected my career...
WRITING.TEXT: Today I was having my regular check in with my boss and she dropped the bomb... "We have some serious concerns." Nothing any of you can do to help, but I just needed to share with someone. I have been seeing a therapist for this and the changes are very slow to come. I feel like I need to fix myself overnight to save this. How do people sit down and write powerpoints and presentations and project plans? I want to gouge my eyes out when I try to do anything like that. I marvel at my type A colleagues that sit down and produce these long documents full of details that I can't read, let alone create. I have been very lucky to get to where I am. I have always been great at what I do and mistakes have often been glossed over because of talent. I have always had great team members that have taken my ideas and put them down on paper and plans to move things along. Now I am in a job that needs more detail and I am struggling. Now my mistakes are $100,000+ mistakes. I did explain that I am working on it, but really at this point in the game, I might have dug the hole too deep. TL;DR: I have missed follow up on some big items. I haven't been able to complete project plans in a timely manner and now my reputation and possibly my entire career is at risk.
No medication, at least not yet. We are working more on techniques to make me more effective. I have had bad reactions to medications in the past, so I am fearful of going down that path again.

Thanks for the kind words. I have a few major projects that I need to buckle down on and get done and I honestly fear that I just can't do that. I need someone to just take my ideas and get them down on paper. I think I need to ask for some sort of support in my job, but I fear that it will be denied and looked upon as a weakness and a waste of resources. I was told to think about how the company can help me and I just am afraid to ask for that type of support when no one else gets that type of support.

I am now in process to trying some of these suggestions. I am hoping now that I am not a "Dead Man Walking" and my efforts will go noticed and they will give me a chance. I have reached out to some folks to help keep me on track. I am purchasing the notebooks you suggested and I am working on a plan to send all my notes every day to a secretary to help keep me on task and remind me when things are due. I have a huge hole to dig out from and hopefully I can do that without losing my job. Thank you all for your kind words and suggestions. I really needed to know there are other people out there dealing with similar issues.

WRITING.TITLE: What is "balanced?"
WRITING.TEXT: So we all know it's a "chemical imbalance" in the brain that causes ADD/ADHD. How do they measure this imbalance of chemicals with manual cognitive testing that doesn't actually take samples from the chemicals in the brain? Am I missing something? Shouldn't there be a measure of balance and then we can focus testing and medications on improving that balance?

I understand the variation in each person, but the question still stands as to why can't we "balance" the chemicals in each individual? We have tremendous abilities to do genetic testing and find out almost everything about a person. Why cant we use that to get this done?
So we continue with "trial and error" as our best option... That seems... Well it seems like it's not very helpful and it causes the cost of treatment to be very high.

So will this article cause changes or will the team just dig in and try to prove to everyone that they are right? This is an issue that so many people in this community have brought up, myself included, and there needs to be systemic changes to how these players are managed.

WRITING.TITLE: Pre-Visit Visits?
WRITING.TEXT: Hello, We have been struggling to get this off the ground. Essentially we want to have a 15 minute visit with an MA/RN to get the rooming process, med reconciliation, and safety questions out of the way before the "actual" visit with the provider starts. It would ideally look like this... 745a-8a appointment with MA 8a-830a appointment with Physician 815a-830a appointment with MA 830a-9a appointment with Physician 845a-9a appointment with MA 9a-930a appointment with Physician and so on... The issue we run into is the "overbooking" in the schedule that screws up data collection and creates double work since we now have to schedule two appointments instead of just one. Does anyone have any experience with this type of scheduling? Thanks in advance for any help!

I find the issue is the same either way. I could schedule patients for 45 minutes, but still run into the issue that the appointments cross into each other. This is specifically for a Diabetes, but the logic stands for any other practice. We have patients that need their pump downloaded prior to the visit with the provider. We would like to eliminate the need for our call reminder system to simply say "Please come 15 minutes early." In turn, we would prefer to have the reminder call say "Your appointment is at 745am." We find that patients will be on time for their appointments and not alway come early. I just want time for the MA/RN to prepare the patient for the provider so that all of the prework is done before the provider walks into the room. Whether that happens in two separate visits or all in the same I don't care. But one the times start crossing, our "Fill Rate" report goes right out the window.

Well this answer is most likely not the complete answer. You might be seeing a locum tenen, which is a doctor that is contracted out to cover the practice while they recruit another full time Physician. I work in healthcare and we do hire locum tenens to bridge the gap of the loss of a Physician and hiring a new one. This happens more often in rural communities that struggle to attract physicians to the area, but does happen in more metropolitan areas as well. You might also be seeing a rotation based practice. Some groups rotate physicians for coverage reasons as well. This is rare, but it happens. Primary Care is in a severe shortage of physicians for some of the reasons above, but that is certainly not the entire answer. That being said, there is a shortage of physicians throughout the country and the trends are not improving. Fellowships across the country are not being filled and this is putting more and more stress on the system. Reform to healthcare would go a long way to bringing talented people back into the profession. Hope this helps!

Do you work in healthcare? Do you know how any of this works?? Physicians have a thankless job, like many of those who choose a profession of service and caregiving. Please do not speak for all of those that have given their lives and careers to the profession. I have had the opportunity to work for and with some amazing physicians and caregivers and can tell you that despite the constant changes and increasing expectations, they still love caring for people and helping people improve their health and wellbeing. Quality measures are put into place so that you know what type of facility and provider will be caring for you. Quality measures help people live longer healthier lives. Yes, those measures take extra time to enter into the computer system, but these are measures that haven't been collected in "the good old days" when physicians couldn't compile data at a macro level to help eliminate disease and illness. Quality measures help us cure complex disease like cancer. If you prefer to move to a country that doesn't measure quality data and doesn't work towards curing diseases and doesn't care about improving the health of everyone in the country, then you will have to find somewhere else to live. This is the reality of medicine. Embrace your increasing longevity and start saving your pennies for your retirement... It's going to be a long one!

These folks manage people that tend to have needs in a very acute way. To the previous poster #8217;s point, most of these patients are behavioral health patients, patients that are distressed in some capacity, or have other social issues that, if the need arises, need to be dealt with quickly and safely.

Oftentimes it #8217;s social work type activities, like calling authorities to help. This might be a situation of a suicidal patient that has an event and the case worker would contact social work, police, etc. to help the individual. There is a connection to the hospital because most of these patients show up in the emergency department (ED) after an event in their lives. This isn #8217;t limited to mental health patients. This could apply to patients or families in abusive relationships or situations as well. Case workers would be called when, for example, a mom and her children show up to the ED with obvious signs of abuse. These folks carry an emotionally heavy load. They deal with situations most of us can #8217;t even imagine.

Well your comment is simply not true. We teach all our physicians to be #8220;insurance blind, #8221; which means they treat the patient and the problem in a medically necessary manner no matter the insurance, or lack there of. We ask for your information so that we can avoid fraud, avoid unnecessary bills to patients, and to ensure that the insurance payer pays for your care. Hospitals give millions of dollars of free care and write offs for patients that can not pay for their care. If you think there was no clinical reason for something your provider ordered, than ask for the reasoning and feel free to question the need, but don #8217;t assume they are ordering unnecessary tests unless you ask some questions first.

I #8217;m not forgetting anything. If you want to attack insurance companies, than go ahead, but your original comment was attacking healthcare providers and workers. Go fight your bill with the hospital and your insurance company. Don #8217;t come here and spew about something you know nothing about.

You bring up an excellent point about price transparency. The charge master is a terrible measure of true cost to the patient. Oftentimes the charge master is inflated to the highest amount any insurer will pay. The average reimbursement for a charge from the hospital is 45-50% of the actual charge. It #8217;s a game that is played between insurers and hospitals. If the hospital bills below reimbursement, then they are leaving money on he table, so they have to charge high amounts to get the best reimbursement from the top payers. Total cost of care is no longer only the price the hospital pays to care for you, it also includes loss of time from work, opportunity costs incurred, anguish, etc.

The article only looks at things that did happen and they draw a very thin line to Bonilla's deal. We pay Bobby Bo every year to do nothing for the organization. Every year $1 million hits our cap because of that deal. So your argument that Bonilla's deal helped us land other players works against you. We now have to work within a smaller cap because of the guaranteed money to Bonilla. That $1 million doesn't get smaller based on time value of money or inflation, that $1 million dollars still hits the cap the same amount every year. The Mets should have considered Bonilla a sunk cost at the time and freed him and the team from his salary burden. We are still living with this and will continue to do so.

As someone who moved here almost 5 years ago, here are my thoughts... Portland and the surrounding areas (20-30 minutes) are great. Portland is a foodie town with tons to do. I have kids and we come into Portland often to enjoy the town. There are great schools in some of the surrounding areas, great outdoor spaces to enjoy, and the people are generally nice. I have been through many more towns further away and some are great places to settle down and spread out. Like any other state, there are nice locations and not so nice locations. Maine has a great beer scene, tons of outdoor options, there are mountains, lakes, ocean and open spaces to enjoy. Tons of hiking and biking trails and just about anything else you want. I would agree about the job market, depending on your skill set, you might find it difficult to find a job. Unemployment here is like 1.5%, historically low and jobs will often see tons of applicants for every job posted. People often complain about the winters, and don't get me wrong, they are long and cold, but people around here are prepared and almost always willing to help out. The summer and fall can't be beat. You'll want to enjoy everything the state has to offer in those seasons. It's a beautiful state with good, salt of the earth people. We plan on staying forever.
Agreed. I came from the Philadelphia area so I was used to large scale events as well, but I actually prefer the smaller more quaint events we get to experience here in Maine.
Think of the rope burn!

More low level jobs than anything. People are employed and move to the next highest bidder when they can. We have seen people move for $0.15 an hour bc they know there are jobs to be had out there. There are very few high paying jobs that open up though.

It's a good thing to promote from within, but not when there are better candidates "from away." The Love far outweighs the heat for me and my family.

First off, MBA over MHA. The business background from an MBA will put you ahead of a lot of people in the field. Also, it opens more doors to you outside of just hospitals. Source: I have my BA in Accounting and MBA and it allowed me to pick from job offers because of my unique background. #8203; As for hospital admin, well that really depends on the culture of the company. I have worked for places that require hefty call requirements, must be able to be reached while on vacation, etc. I have also worked for companies that value time away and encourage it. Places that tell you to turn off and enjoy and come back recharged. You will have to figure that out in your process. Working for a hospital system will more than likely feel like you are tied to the job more since it is a 24/7/365 company.

I agree, to some extent. Most guys coming out of high school and college are expected to play multiple positions. This is also one of the reasons CF, SS, and 2B are highly valued, because the expectation is that if they can play those positions, they can play any of the other positions on the field. All of that being said, the Mets refuse to allow a player to grow and learn a position over time because they are trying to force feed them into the big league lineup. They do this by moving them around to whatever position currently has the most people hurt. This does not allow a player to learn a new position, grow, and flourish in that position. I would like to see a better focus on athletic position players that can play up the middle, then move them to areas of need and let them learn that position, get comfortable, and see if they can flourish. This all takes time.

Where do I start? Yes, this is 100% normal. Crossfit is hard, but you are doing the most important thing, which is showing up and working hard. Take a step back a realize that there are so many different movements that you have learned in the past 7 months. How many times did you hit your old gym and work on snatches? How many times did you crank out a bunch of burpees and then hop on a rower? Crossfit pushes you in ways no other workout will. It it totally normal to still feel like you are catching up. I #8217;ve only been Crossfitting for 15 months and there are so many things I either can #8217;t do or really struggle with. Cardio is still one of those things. Just remember that cardio heavy days also usually have some other movements that make it hard to recover your breathing and that #8217;s why the second and third rounds are way harder than they would be if you were just running. Think about all the things you #8217;ve learned so far and focus on improving each day, not matter how small the improvement. After a year you will look back and be amazed. You are right where you should be in your journey. Now just keep showing up and working hard. Your coaches are doing the right thing by scaling you back. Trust the process. Good luck!!
